1187.description: Tissue engineer and TED Fellow Nina Tandon is growing artificial hearts and bones. To do that, she needs new ways of caring for artificially grown cells -- techniques she's developed by the simple but powerful method of copying their natural environments.
1187.author: Nina Tandon
1187.keywords: TED, talks, TED Fellows, biology, biomimicry, biotech, science

1188.title: Let's take back the Internet!
1188.description: In this powerful talk from TEDGlobal, Rebecca MacKinnon describes the expanding struggle for freedom and control in cyberspace, and asks: How do we design the next phase of the Internet with accountability and freedom at its core, rather than control? She believes the internet is headed for a "Magna Carta" moment when citizens around the world demand that their governments protect free speech and their right to connection.
1188.author: Rebecca MacKinnon
1188.keywords: TED, talks, culture, protests, social media, surveillance, encryption

1189.title: A global culture to fight extremism
1189.description: Why do transnational extremist organizations succeed where democratic movements have a harder time taking hold? Maajid Nawaz, a former Islamist extremist, asks for new grassroots stories and global social activism to spread democracy in the face of nationalism and xenophobia.
1189.author: Maajid Nawaz
1189.keywords: TED, talks, culture, democracy, global issues, politics

1190.title: Trial, error and the God complex
1190.description: Economics writer Tim Harford studies complex systems -- and finds a surprising link among the successful ones: they were built through trial and error. In this sparkling talk from TEDGlobal 2011, he asks us to embrace our randomness and start making better mistakes.
1190.author: Tim Harford
1190.keywords: TED, talks, business, creativity, culture, society

1191.title: See Yemen through my eyes
1191.description: As political turmoil in Yemen continues, the editor of the Yemen Times, Nadia Al-Sakkaf, talks at TEDGlobal with host Pat Mitchell. Al-Sakkaf's independent, English-language paper is vital for sharing news -- and for sharing a new vision of Yemen and of that country's women as equal partners in work and change.
1191.author: Nadia Al-Sakkaf
1191.keywords: TED, talks, communication, global issues, journalism, war, women

1192.title: Fighting viruses, defending the net
1192.description: It's been 25 years since the first PC virus (Brain A) hit the net, and what was once an annoyance has become a sophisticated tool for crime and espionage. Computer security expert Mikko Hyppönen tells us how we can stop these new viruses from threatening the internet as we know it.
1192.author: Mikko Hypponen
1192.keywords: TED, talks, Internet, TEDx, computers, crime, global issues, technology, virus

1193.title: Embracing otherness, embracing myself
1193.description: Actor Thandie Newton tells the story of finding her "otherness" -- first, as a child growing up in two distinct cultures, and then as an actor playing with many different selves. A warm, wise talk, fresh from stage at TEDGlobal 2011.
1193.author: Thandie Newton
1193.keywords: TED, talks, culture, entertainment, psychology, self, film

1194.title: How algorithms shape our world
1194.description: We live in a world run by algorithms, computer programs that make decisions or solve problems for us. In this riveting, funny talk, Kevin Slavin shows how modern algorithms determine stock prices, espionage tactics, even the movies you watch. But, he asks: If we depend on complex algorithms to manage our daily decisions -- when do we start to lose control?
1194.author: Kevin Slavin
1194.keywords: TED, talks, complexity, computers, social change, technology

1196.title: Time to end the war in Afghanistan
1196.description: British MP Rory Stewart walked across Afghanistan after 9/11, talking with citizens and warlords alike. Now, a decade later, he asks: Why are Western and coalition forces still fighting there? He shares lessons from past military interventions that worked -- Bosnia, for instance -- and shows that humility and local expertise are the keys to success.
1196.author: Rory Stewart
1196.keywords: TED, talks, Foreign Policy, Middle East, global issues, military, peace, war

1197.title: The surprising math of cities and corporations
1197.description: Physicist Geoffrey West has found that simple, mathematical laws govern the properties of cities -- that wealth, crime rate, walking speed and many other aspects of a city can be deduced from a single number: the city's population. In this mind-bending talk from TEDGlobal he shows how it works and how similar laws hold for organisms and corporations.
1197.author: Geoffrey West
1197.keywords: TED, talks, biology, business, cities, complexity, math, science, infrastructure

1198.title: The origins of pleasure
1198.description: Why do we like an original painting better than a forgery? Psychologist Paul Bloom argues that human beings are essentialists -- that our beliefs about the history of an object change how we experience it, not simply as an illusion, but as a deep feature of what pleasure (and pain) is.
1198.author: Paul Bloom
1198.keywords: TED, talks, happiness, philosophy, psychology, science

1199.title: Ending hunger now
1199.description: Josette Sheeran, the head of the UN's World Food Program, talks about why, in a world with enough food for everyone, people still go hungry, still die of starvation, still use food as a weapon of war. Her vision: "Food is one issue that cannot be solved person by person. We have to stand together."
1199.author: Josette Sheeran
1199.keywords: TED, talks, culture, economics, food, global issues, peace, politics, war

1201.title: After your final status update
1201.description: Many of us have a social media presence -- a virtual personality made up of status updates, tweets and connections, stored in the cloud. Adam Ostrow asks a big question: What happens to that personality after you've died? Could it ... live on?
1201.author: Adam Ostrow
1201.keywords: TED, talks, consciousness, culture, self, social change, social media, technology

1202.title: Wireless data from every light bulb
1202.description: What if every light bulb in the world could also transmit data? At TEDGlobal, Harald Haas demonstrates, for the first time, a device that could do exactly that. By flickering the light from a single LED, a change too quick for the human eye to detect, he can transmit far more data than a cellular tower -- and do it in a way that's more efficient, secure and widespread.
1202.author: Harald Haas
1202.keywords: TED, talks, Internet, cities, invention, technology

1203.title: How language transformed humanity
1203.description: Biologist Mark Pagel shares an intriguing theory about why humans evolved our complex system of language. He suggests that language is a piece of "social technology" that allowed early human tribes to access a powerful new tool: cooperation.
1203.author: Mark Pagel
1203.keywords: TED, talks, biology, communication, culture, evolution, language, science

1204.title: Are we filtering the wrong microbes?
1204.description: Should we keep the outdoors out of hospitals? Ecologist and TED Fellow Jessica Green has found that mechanical ventilation does get rid of many types of microbes, but the wrong kinds: the ones left in the hospital are much more likely to be pathogens.
1204.author: Jessica Green
1204.keywords: TED, talks, TED Fellows, health, microbiology, science

1205.title: Suddenly, my body
1205.description: Poet, writer, activist Eve Ensler lived in her head. In this powerful talk from TEDWomen, she talks about her lifelong disconnection from her body -- and how two shocking events helped her to connect with the reality, the physicality of being human.
1205.author: Eve Ensler
1205.keywords: TED, talks, activism, brain, cancer, culture, poetry, human body

1206.title: The demise of guys?
1206.description: (NOTE: Statements in this talk have been challenged by scientists working in this field. Please read "Criticisms & Updates" below for more details.) Psychologist Philip Zimbardo asks, "Why are boys struggling?" He shares some stats (lower graduation rates, greater worries about intimacy and relationships) and suggests a few reasons -- and challenges the TED community to think about solutions.
1206.author: Philip Zimbardo
1206.keywords: TED, talks, culture, feminism, gaming, gender, sex

1207.title: The shareable future of cities
1207.description: How can cities help save the future? Alex Steffen shows some cool neighborhood-based green projects that expand our access to things we want and need -- while reducing the time we spend in cars.
1207.author: Alex Steffen
1207.keywords: TED, talks, architecture, cities, collaboration, design, energy, environment, green, technology, infrastructure

1209.title: One day of peace
1209.description: Here's a crazy idea: Persuade the world to try living in peace for just one day, every September 21. In this energetic, honest talk, Jeremy Gilley tells the story of how this crazy idea became real -- real enough to help millions of kids in war-torn regions.
1209.author: Jeremy Gilley
1209.keywords: TED, talks, activism, collaboration, global issues, peace, war, nonviolence

1210.title: Finding planets around other stars
1210.description: How do we find planets -- even habitable planets -- around other stars? By looking for tiny dimming as a planet passes in front of its sun, TED Fellow Lucianne Walkowicz and the Kepler mission have found some 1,200 potential new planetary systems. With new techniques, they may even find ones with the right conditions for life.
1210.author: Lucianne Walkowicz
1210.keywords: TED, talks, TED Fellows, exploration, science, technology, universe, telescopes, Sun

1212.title: Beware conflicts of interest
1212.description: In this short talk, psychologist Dan Ariely tells two personal stories that explore scientific conflict of interest: How the pursuit of knowledge and insight can be affected, consciously or not, by shortsighted personal goals. When we're thinking about the big questions, he reminds us, let's be aware of our all-too-human brains.
1212.author: Dan Ariely
1212.keywords: TED, talks, cognitive science, economics, medical research, science, technology

1213.title: DNA clues to our inner neanderthal
1213.description: Sharing the results of a massive, worldwide study, geneticist Svante Pääbo shows the DNA proof that early humans mated with Neanderthals after we moved out of Africa. (Yes, many of us have Neanderthal DNA.) He also shows how a tiny bone from a baby finger was enough to identify a whole new humanoid species.
1213.author: Svante Pääbo
1213.keywords: TED, talks, DNA, biology, evolution, science

1214.title: Pay attention to nonviolence
1214.description: In 2003, the Palestinian village of Budrus mounted a 10-month-long nonviolent protest to stop a barrier being built across their olive groves. Did you hear about it? Didn't think so. Brazilian filmmaker Julia Bacha asks why we only pay attention to violence in the Israel-Palestine conflict -- and not to the nonviolent leaders who may one day bring peace.
1214.author: Julia Bacha
1214.keywords: TED, talks, communication, compassion, entertainment, film, peace, violence, war, nonviolence

1215.title: Can we make things that make themselves?
1215.description: MIT researcher Skylar Tibbits works on self-assembly -- the idea that instead of building something (a chair, a skyscraper), we can create materials that build themselves, much the way a strand of DNA zips itself together. It's a big concept at early stages; Tibbits shows us three in-the-lab projects that hint at what a self-assembling future might look like.
1215.author: Skylar Tibbits
1215.keywords: TED, talks, TED Fellows, design, technology

1216.title: Compassion and the true meaning of empathy
1216.description: Buddhist roshi Joan Halifax works with people at the last stage of life (in hospice and on death row). She shares what she's learned about compassion in the face of death and dying, and a deep insight into the nature of empathy.
1216.author: Joan Halifax
1216.keywords: TED, talks, Buddhism, compassion, culture, death, global issues

1217.title: Unintended consequences
1217.description: Every new invention changes the world -- in ways both intentional and unexpected. Historian Edward Tenner tells stories that illustrate the under-appreciated gap between our ability to innovate and our ability to foresee the consequences.
1217.author: Edward Tenner
1217.keywords: TED, talks, culture, design, history, invention, technology

1218.title: Making matter come alive
1218.description: Before life existed on Earth, there was just matter, inorganic dead "stuff." How improbable is it that life arose? And -- could it use a different type of chemistry? Using an elegant definition of life (anything that can evolve), chemist Lee Cronin is exploring this question by attempting to create a fully inorganic cell using a "Lego kit" of inorganic molecules -- no carbon -- that can assemble, replicate and compete.
1218.author: Lee Cronin
1218.keywords: TED, talks, biology, life, nanoscale, science, marine biology

1219.title: Shake up your story
1219.description: Artist Raghava KK demos his new children's book for iPad with a fun feature: when you shake it, the story -- and your perspective -- changes. In this charming short talk, he invites all of us to shake up our perspective a little bit.
1219.author: Raghava KK
1219.keywords: TED, talks, creativity, design, entertainment, technology, books, storytelling

1220.title: Does democracy stifle economic growth?
1220.description: Economist Yasheng Huang compares China to India, and asks how China's authoritarian rule contributed to its astonishing economic growth -- leading to a big question: Is democracy actually holding India back? Huang's answer may surprise you.
1220.author: Yasheng Huang
1220.keywords: TED, talks, Asia, culture, democracy, economics, global issues, politics, india

1221.title: Hire the hackers!
1221.description: Despite multibillion-dollar investments in cybersecurity, one of its root problems has been largely ignored: who are the people who write malicious code? Underworld investigator Misha Glenny profiles several convicted coders from around the world and reaches a startling conclusion.
1221.author: Misha Glenny
1221.keywords: TED, talks, Internet, computers, crime, global issues, technology

1222.title: The art of wearable communication
1222.description: Artist Kate Hartman uses wearable electronics to explore how we communicate, with ourselves and with the world. In this quirky and thought-provoking talk, she shows the "Talk to Yourself Hat", the "Inflatable Heart", the "Glacier Embracing Suit", and other unexpected devices.
1222.author: Kate Hartman
1222.keywords: TED, talks, art, communication, culture, glacier

1224.title: The conscience of television
1224.description: TV executive Lauren Zalaznick thinks deeply about pop television. Sharing results of a bold study that tracks attitudes against TV ratings over five decades, she makes a case that television reflects who we truly are -- in ways we might not have expected.
1224.author: Lauren Zalaznick

1226.title: The 6 killer apps of prosperity
1226.description: Over the past few centuries, Western cultures have been very good at creating general prosperity for themselves. Historian Niall Ferguson asks: Why the West, and less so the rest? He suggests half a dozen big ideas from Western culture -- call them the 6 killer apps -- that promote wealth, stability and innovation. And in this new century, he says, these apps are all shareable.
1226.author: Niall Ferguson
1226.keywords: TED, talks, business, culture, economics, global issues

1227.title: What we learned from 5 million books
1227.description: Have you played with Google Labs' Ngram Viewer? It's an addicting tool that lets you search for words and ideas in a database of 5 million books from across centuries. Erez Lieberman Aiden and Jean-Baptiste Michel show us how it works, and a few of the surprising things we can learn from 500 billion words.
1227.author: Jean-Baptiste Michel + Erez Lieberman Aiden
1227.keywords: TED, talks, Google, TEDx, data, design, library, technology, visualizations, writing

1228.title: Selling condoms in the Congo
1228.description: HIV is a serious problem in the DR Congo, and aid agencies have flooded the country with free and cheap condoms. But few people are using them. Why? "Reformed marketer" Amy Lockwood offers a surprising answer that upends a traditional model of philanthropy. (Some NSFW images.)
1228.author: Amy Lockwood
1228.keywords: TED, talks, Africa, business, global issues, marketing, philanthropy, HIV

1229.title: Fighting a contagious cancer
1229.description: What is killing the Tasmanian devil? A virulent cancer is infecting them by the thousands  -- and unlike most cancers, it's contagious. Researcher Elizabeth Murchison tells us how she's fighting to save the Taz, and what she's learning about all cancers from this unusual strain. Contains disturbing images of facial cancer.
1229.author: Elizabeth Murchison
1229.keywords: TED, talks, animals, biology, cancer, science

1230.title: Doodlers, unite!
1230.description: Studies show that sketching and doodling improve our comprehension -- and our creative thinking. So why do we still feel embarrassed when we're caught doodling in a meeting? Sunni Brown says: Doodlers, unite! She makes the case for unlocking your brain via pad and pen.
1230.author: Sunni Brown
1230.keywords: TED, talks, business, creativity, culture, presentation

1231.title: A doctor's touch
1231.description: Modern medicine is in danger of losing a powerful, old-fashioned tool: human touch. Physician and writer Abraham Verghese describes our strange new world where patients are merely data points, and calls for a return to the traditional one-on-one physical exam.
1231.author: Abraham Verghese
1231.keywords: TED, talks, communication, culture, health, health care, medicine, science

1232.title: A short intro to the Studio School
1232.description: Some kids learn by listening; others learn by doing. Geoff Mulgan gives a short introduction to the Studio School, a new kind of school in the UK where small teams of kids learn by working on projects that are, as Mulgan puts it, "for real."
1232.author: Geoff Mulgan
1232.keywords: TED, talks, creativity, culture, design, education, work

1233.title: Filming democracy in Ghana
1233.description: Jarreth Merz, a Swiss-Ghanaian filmmaker, came to Ghana in 2008 to film the national elections. What he saw there taught him new lessons about democracy -- and about himself.
1233.author: Jarreth Merz
1233.keywords: TED, talks, Africa, democracy, entertainment, film, global issues, politics

1236.title: The generation that's remaking China
1236.description: Yang Lan, a journalist and entrepreneur who's been called "the Oprah of China," offers insight into the next generation of young Chinese citizens -- urban, connected (via microblogs) and alert to injustice.
1236.author: Yang Lan
1236.keywords: TED, talks, Asia, china, economics, global issues, media, politics

1238.title: Less stuff, more happiness
1238.description: Writer and designer Graham Hill asks: Can having less stuff, in less room, lead to more happiness? He makes the case for taking up less space, and lays out three rules for editing your life.
1238.author: Graham Hill
1238.keywords: TED, talks, consumerism, culture, design, happiness, media, simplicity

1239.title: We can recycle plastic
1239.description: Less than 10% of plastic trash is recycled -- compared to almost 90% of metals -- because of the massively complicated problem of finding and sorting the different kinds. Frustrated by this waste, Mike Biddle has developed a cheap and incredibly energy efficient plant that can, and does, recycle any kind of plastic.
1239.author: Mike Biddle
1239.keywords: TED, talks, business, global issues, green, plastic, technology

1240.title: Trusting the ensemble
1240.description: Conductor Charles Hazlewood talks about the role of trust in musical leadership -- then shows how it works, as he conducts the Scottish Ensemble onstage. He also shares clips from two musical projects: the opera "U-Carmen eKhayelitsha" and the ParaOrchestra.
1240.author: Charles Hazlewood
1240.keywords: TED, talks, collaboration, conducting, culture, entertainment, music, trust, live music

1241.title: What do babies think?
1241.description: "Babies and young children are like the R&D division of the human species," says psychologist Alison Gopnik. Her research explores the sophisticated intelligence-gathering and decision-making that babies are really doing when they play.
1241.author: Alison Gopnik
1241.keywords: TED, talks, brain, children, culture, education, psychology

1242.title: How mobile phones helped solve two murders
1242.description: Two murders sat unexplained and unsolved -- until reporter Paul Lewis starting talking to bystanders who had evidence on their mobile phones. Step by step, Lewis pieced together their evidence and their stories to find justice for the victims. It's the future of investigative journalism, powered by the crowd.
1242.author: Paul Lewis
1242.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, cities, collaboration, culture, global issues, journalism, social media

1243.title: How beauty feels
1243.description: A story, a work of art, a face, a designed object -- how do we tell that something is beautiful?  And why does it matter so much to us? Designer Richard Seymour explores our response to beauty and the surprising power of objects that exhibit it.
1243.author: Richard Seymour
1243.keywords: TED, talks, Senses, beauty, design, happiness, art

1244.title: The day I turned down Tim Berners-Lee
1244.description: Imagine it's late 1990, and you've just met a nice young man named Tim Berners-Lee, who starts telling you about his proposed system called the World Wide Web. Ian Ritchie was there. And ... he didn't buy it. A short story about information, connectivity and learning from mistakes.
1244.author: Ian Ritchie
1244.keywords: TED, talks, business, history, technology, web

1245.title: Open science now!
1245.description: What if every scientist could share their data as easily as they tweet about their lunch? Michael Nielsen calls for scientists to embrace new tools for collaboration that will enable discoveries to happen at the speed of Twitter.
1245.author: Michael Nielsen
1245.keywords: TED, talks, Internet, TEDx, collaboration, open-source, science, technology, crowdsourcing, data

1247.title: My mushroom burial suit
1247.description: Here's a powerful provocation from artist Jae Rhim Lee. Can we commit our bodies to a cleaner, greener Earth, even after death? Naturally -- using a special burial suit seeded with pollution-gobbling mushrooms. Yes, this just might be the strangest TEDTalk you'll ever see ...
1247.author: Jae Rhim Lee
1247.keywords: TED, talks, TED Fellows, death, design, green, invention, art, fungi

1248.title: Learning from a barefoot movement
1248.description: In Rajasthan, India, an extraordinary school teaches rural women and men -- many of them illiterate -- to become solar engineers, artisans, dentists and doctors in their own villages. It's called the Barefoot College, and its founder, Bunker Roy, explains how it works.
1248.author: Bunker Roy
1248.keywords: TED, talks, culture, education, global issues, india, invention, women, global development

1249.title: Freeing energy from the grid
1249.description: What would happen if we could generate power from our windowpanes? In this moving talk, entrepreneur Justin Hall-Tipping shows the materials that could make that possible, and how questioning our notion of 'normal' can lead to extraordinary breakthroughs.
1249.author: Justin Hall-Tipping
1249.keywords: TED, talks, energy, entrepreneur, environment, science, technology, electricity

1250.title: How cyberattacks threaten real-world peace
1250.description: Nations can now attack other nations with cyber weapons: silent strikes on another country's computer systems, power grids, dams that leave no trace behind. (Think of the Stuxnet worm.) Guy-Philippe Goldstein shows how cyberattacks can leap between the digital and physical worlds to prompt armed conflict -- and how we might avert this global security hazard.
1250.author: Guy-Philippe Goldstein
1250.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, computers, global issues, politics, security, technology, terrorism, war

1251.title: A prosthetic arm that "feels"
1251.description: Physiatrist and engineer Todd Kuiken is building a prosthetic arm that connects with the human nervous system -- improving motion, control and even feeling. Onstage, patient Amanda Kitts helps demonstrate this next-gen robotic arm.
1251.author: Todd Kuiken
1251.keywords: TED, talks, Senses, design, engineering, invention, medicine, prosthetics, science, technology, bionics

1252.title: Art made of storms
1252.description: Artist Nathalie Miebach takes weather data from massive storms and turns it into complex sculptures that embody the forces of nature and time. These sculptures then become musical scores for a string quartet to play.
1252.author: Nathalie Miebach
1252.keywords: TED, talks, TED Fellows, art, data, visualizations, weather

1253.title: How economic inequality harms societies
1253.description: We feel instinctively that societies with huge income gaps are somehow going wrong. Richard Wilkinson charts the hard data on economic inequality, and shows what gets worse when rich and poor are too far apart: real effects on health, lifespan, even such basic values as trust.
1253.author: Richard Wilkinson
1253.keywords: TED, talks, culture, data, global issues, inequality, money, social change, visualizations

1255.title: The strange tale of the Norden bombsight
1255.description: Master storyteller Malcolm Gladwell tells the tale of the Norden bombsight, a groundbreaking piece of World War II technology with a deeply unexpected result.
1255.author: Malcolm Gladwell

1257.title: Stories cut from paper
1257.description: With scissors and paper, artist Béatrice Coron creates intricate worlds, cities and countries, heavens and hells. Striding onstage in a glorious cape cut from Tyvek, she describes her creative process and the way her stories develop from snips and slices.
1257.author: Béatrice Coron

1258.title: FBI, here I am!
1258.description: After he ended up on a watch list by accident, Hasan Elahi was advised by his local FBI agents to let them know when he was traveling. He did that and more ... much more.
1258.author: Hasan Elahi
1258.keywords: TED, talks, art, data, security, war, web, surveillance

1259.title: Trust, morality -- and oxytocin?
1259.description: (NOTE: Research and statements in this talk have been challenged by other scientists working in this field. Please read "Criticisms & Updates" below for more details.) What drives our desire to behave morally? Neuroeconomist Paul Zak shows why he believes oxytocin (he calls it "the moral molecule") is responsible for trust, empathy and other feelings that help build a stable society.
1259.author: Paul Zak
1259.keywords: TED, talks, brain, culture, medicine, morality, science, chemistry, neuroscience, behavioral economics, molecular biology, sociology, biology, happiness, empathy, psychology, mind, cognitive science

1260.title: A plane you can drive
1260.description: A flying car -- it's an iconic image of the future. But after 100 years of flight and automotive engineering, no one has really cracked the problem. Pilot Anna Mracek Dietrich and her team flipped the question, asking: Why not build a plane that you can drive?
1260.author: Anna Mracek Dietrich
1260.keywords: TED, talks, cars, design, flight, invention, transportation

1261.title: The real reason for brains
1261.description: Neuroscientist Daniel Wolpert starts from a surprising premise: the brain evolved, not to think or feel, but to control movement. In this entertaining, data-rich talk he gives us a glimpse into how the brain creates the grace and agility of human motion.
1261.author: Daniel Wolpert
1261.keywords: TED, talks, biology, brain, evolution, science, math, biomechanics, AI, engineering, robots, neuroscience, decision-making, consciousness, cognitive science

1262.title: Augmented reality, techno-magic
1262.description: Using sleight-of-hand techniques and charming storytelling, illusionist Marco Tempest brings a jaunty stick figure to life onstage at TEDGlobal.
1262.author: Marco Tempest

1264.title: The line between life and not-life
1264.description: In his lab, Martin Hanczyc makes "protocells," experimental blobs of chemicals that behave like living cells. His work demonstrates how life might have first occurred on Earth ... and perhaps elsewhere too.
1264.author: Martin Hanczyc
1264.keywords: TED, talks, biology, chemistry, life, science, molecular biology, AI, evolution, ecology, human origins, innovation, nanoscale

1265.title: High-tech art (with a sense of humor)
1265.description: Artist and TED Fellow Aparna Rao re-imagines the familiar in surprising, often humorous ways. With her collaborator Soren Pors, Rao creates high-tech art installations -- a typewriter that sends emails, a camera that tracks you through the room only to make you invisible on screen -- that put a playful spin on ordinary objects and interactions.
1265.author: Aparna Rao
1265.keywords: TED, talks, TED Fellows, art, creativity, humor, technology

1266.title: Ancient wonders captured in 3D
1266.description: Ancient monuments give us clues to astonishing past civilizations -- but they're under threat from pollution, war, neglect. Ben Kacyra, who invented a groundbreaking 3D scanning system, is using his invention to scan and preserve the world's heritage in archival detail. (Watch to the end for a little demo.)
1266.author: Ben Kacyra
1266.keywords: TED, talks, history, invention, technology, archaeology

1267.title: A map of the brain
1267.description: How can we begin to understand the way the brain works? The same way we begin to understand a city: by making a map. In this visually stunning talk, Allan Jones shows how his team is mapping which genes are turned on in each tiny region, and how it all connects up.
1267.author: Allan Jones
1267.keywords: TED, talks, brain, disease, science, technology, genetics, neuroscience, molecular biology, biotech, mental health, physiology, medical research, medical imaging, cognitive science, visualizations, DNA

1268.title: 6 ways to save the internet
1268.description: The next big shift is now, and it's not what you think: Facebook is the new Windows; Google must be sacrificed. Tech investor Roger McNamee presents 6 bold ways to prepare for the next internet.
1268.author: Roger McNamee
1268.keywords: TED, talks, Internet, TEDx, business, future, investment, technology

1274.title: Experiments that hint of longer lives
1274.description: What controls aging? Biochemist Cynthia Kenyon has found a simple genetic mutation that can double the lifespan of a simple worm, C. elegans. The lessons from that discovery, and others, are pointing to how we might one day significantly extend youthful human life.
1274.author: Cynthia Kenyon
1274.keywords: TED, talks, aging, biotech, genetics, medicine, science, technology, molecular biology, synthetic biology, innovation, medical research, DNA

1276.title: Science versus wonder?
1276.description: Does science ruin the magic of life? In this grumpy but charming monologue, Robin Ince makes the argument against. The more we learn about the astonishing behavior of the universe -- the more we stand in awe.
1276.author: Robin Ince
1276.keywords: TED, talks, comedy, entertainment, science, time, philosophy, science and art, humor

1278.title: How games make kids smarter
1278.description: Can playing video games make you more productive? Gabe Zichermann shows how games are making kids better problem-solvers, and will make us better at everything from driving to multi-tasking.
1278.author: Gabe Zichermann
1278.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, design, education, gaming, play

1281.title: Meet Rezero, the dancing ballbot
1281.description: Engineering student Péter Fankhauser demonstrates Rezero, a robot that balances on a ball. Designed and built by students, Rezero is the first ballbot made to move quickly and gracefully -- and even dance. (Could the Star Wars sphere droid be real? Watch this and judge.)
1281.author: Péter Fankhauser
1281.keywords: TED, talks, creativity, design, engineering, robots, technology

1282.title: The technology of storytelling
1282.description: iPad storyteller Joe Sabia introduces us to Lothar Meggendorfer, who created a bold technology for storytelling: the pop-up book. Sabia shows how new technology has always helped us tell our own stories, from the walls of caves to his own onstage iPad.
1282.author: Joe Sabia
1282.keywords: TED, talks, creativity, design, entertainment, storytelling, technology

1286.title: Philosophy in prison
1286.description: Damon Horowitz teaches philosophy through the Prison University Project, bringing college-level classes to inmates of San Quentin State Prison. In this powerful short talk, he tells the story of an encounter with right and wrong that quickly gets personal.
1286.author: Damon Horowitz
1286.keywords: TED, talks, crime, culture, global issues, philosophy, prison

1287.title: Don't regret regret
1287.description: We're taught to try to live life without regret. But why? Using her own tattoo as an example, Kathryn Schulz makes a powerful and moving case for embracing our regrets.
1287.author: Kathryn Schulz

1288.title: How to stop torture
1288.description: Political prisoners aren't the only ones being tortured -- the vast majority of judicial torture happens in ordinary cases, even in 'functioning' legal systems. Social activist Karen Tse shows how we can, and should, stand up and end the use of routine torture.
1288.author: Karen Tse
1288.keywords: TED, talks, global issues, law, politics, prison, war, criminal justice, justice system

1289.title: What we learn before we're born
1289.description: Pop quiz: When does learning begin? Answer: Before we are born. Science writer Annie Murphy Paul talks through new research that shows how much we learn in the womb -- from the lilt of our native language to our soon-to-be-favorite foods.
1289.author: Annie Murphy Paul
1289.keywords: TED, talks, children, education, food, science, writing, pregnancy, culture, brain, neuroscience, evolution, mental health

1290.title: Dance vs. powerpoint, a modest proposal
1290.description: Instead of a boring slide deck at your next presentation, how about bringing in a troupe of dancers? That's science writer John Bohannon's "modest proposal" in this spellbinding choreographed talk. He makes his case by example, in collaboration with dancers from Black Label Movement.
1290.author: John Bohannon
1290.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, biology, dance, entertainment, physics, presentation, science, technology, science and art

1291.title: Building the musical muscle
1291.description: Charles Limb performs cochlear implantation, a surgery that treats hearing loss and can restore the ability to hear speech. But as a musician too, Limb thinks about what the implants lack: They don't let you fully experience music yet. (There's a hair-raising example.) At TEDMED, Limb reviews the state of the art and the way forward.
1291.author: Charles Limb
1291.keywords: TED, talks, beauty, medical research, music, science, technology, disability, Senses, hearing, art, science and art, sound

1292.title: Don't misrepresent Africa
1292.description: Real narratives are complicated: Africa isn't a country, and it's not a disaster zone, says reporter and researcher Leslie Dodson. She calls for journalists, researchers and NGOs to stop representing entire continents as one big tragedy.
1292.author: Leslie Dodson
1292.keywords: TED, talks, Africa, TEDx, journalism, media, poverty

1293.title: How many lives can you live?
1293.description: Spoken-word poet Sarah Kay was stunned to find she couldn't be a princess, ballerina and astronaut all in one lifetime. In this talk, she delivers two powerful poems that show us how we can live other lives. Sarah is also the host of TED's podcast "Sincerely, X." You can listen on the Luminary podcast app at luminary.link/ted.
1293.author: Sarah Kay
1293.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, entertainment, poetry, spoken word, performance, performance art, storytelling

1296.title: The magnificence of spider silk
1296.description: Cheryl Hayashi studies spider silk, one of nature's most high-performance materials. Each species of spider can make up to 7 very different kinds of silk. How do they do it? Hayashi explains at the DNA level -- then shows us how this super-strong, super-flexible material can inspire.
1296.author: Cheryl Hayashi
1296.keywords: TED, talks, MacArthur grant, biomechanics, biomimicry, science, technology, materials, molecular biology, biotech, engineering, industrial design, nature, insects, web, physics

1297.title: Ultrasound surgery -- healing without cuts
1297.description: Imagine having a surgery with no knives involved. At TEDMED, Yoav Medan shares a technique that uses MRI to find trouble spots and focused ultrasound to treat such issues as brain lesions, uterine fibroids and several kinds of cancerous growths.
1297.author: Yoav Medan
1297.keywords: TED, talks, health care, medical research, medicine, science, technology, biotech, engineering, sound, neuroscience, future, innovation, physics, medical imaging

1298.title: There are no mistakes on the bandstand
1298.description: What is a mistake? By talking through examples with his improvisational jazz quartet, Stefon Harris walks us to a profound truth: many actions are perceived as mistakes only because we don't react to them appropriately.
1298.author: Stefon Harris
1298.keywords: TED, talks, culture, entertainment, jazz, music, live music

1299.title: The world's smallest 3D printer
1299.description: What could you do with the world's smallest 3D printer? Klaus Stadlmann demos his tiny, affordable printer that could someday make customized hearing aids -- or sculptures smaller than a human hair.
1299.author: Klaus Stadlmann
1299.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, design, engineering, industrial design, technology

1301.title: The hidden light of Afghanistan
1301.description: Photographer Monika Bulaj shares powerful, intimate images of Afghanistan -- of home life, of ritual, of men and women. Behind the headlines, what does the world truly know about this place?
1301.author: Monika Bulaj
1301.keywords: TED, talks, TED Fellows, design, global issues, journalism, photography, storytelling, art

1302.title: Color-coded surgery
1302.description: Surgeons are taught from textbooks which conveniently color-code the types of tissues, but that's not what it looks like in real life -- until now. At TEDMED Quyen Nguyen demonstrates how a molecular marker can make tumors light up in neon green, showing surgeons exactly where to cut.
1302.author: Quyen Nguyen
1302.keywords: TED, talks, cancer, medicine, science, technology, biotech, Nobel Prize, molecular biology, biology, health care, medical research, Surgery, innovation

1303.title: Put a value on nature!
1303.description: Every day, we use materials from the earth without thinking, for free. But what if we had to pay for their true value: would it make us more careful about what we use and what we waste? Think of Pavan Sukhdev as nature's banker -- assessing the value of the Earth's assets. Eye-opening charts will make you think differently about the cost of air, water, trees ...
1303.author: Pavan Sukhdev
1303.keywords: TED, talks, business, economics, finance, global issues, green

1304.title: Cooking as alchemy
1304.description: Homaro Cantu and Ben Roche come from Moto, a Chicago restaurant that plays with new ways to cook and eat food. But beyond the fun and flavor-tripping, there's a serious intent: Can we use new food technology for good?
1304.author: Homaro Cantu + Ben Roche
1304.keywords: TED, talks, agriculture, business, creativity, culture, food

1306.title: My subversive (garden) plot
1306.description: A vegetable garden can do more than save you money -- it can save the world. In this talk, Roger Doiron shows how gardens can re-localize our food and feed our growing population.
1306.author: Roger Doiron
1306.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, culture, food, garden, global issues, sustainability

1307.title: Medicine for the 99 percent
1307.description: Sad but true: Many of the cures and vaccines our world desperately needs -- for illnesses millions of people have -- just aren't being produced or developed, because there's no financial incentive. Thomas Pogge proposes a $6 billion plan to revolutionize the way medications are developed and sold.
1307.author: Thomas Pogge
1307.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, economics, global issues, health

1308.title: The quest to understand consciousness
1308.description: Every morning we wake up and regain consciousness -- that is a marvelous fact -- but what exactly is it that we regain? Neuroscientist Antonio Damasio uses this simple question to give us a glimpse into how our brains create our sense of self.
1308.author: Antonio Damasio
1308.keywords: TED, talks, brain, consciousness, neuroscience, science, self, mind, medical imaging, cognitive science, decision-making, identity, medical research, Senses, memory, mental health

1309.title: A prosthetic eye to treat blindness
1309.description: At TEDMED, Sheila Nirenberg shows a bold way to create sight in people with certain kinds of blindness: by hooking into the optic nerve and sending signals from a camera direct to the brain.
1309.author: Sheila Nirenberg
1309.keywords: TED, talks, medical research, medicine, science, sight, technology, prosthetics, Senses, disability, biotech, engineering, innovation, code, neuroscience, Surgery, brain

1310.title: The battle between your present and future self
1310.description: Every day, we make decisions that have good or bad consequences for our future selves. (Can I skip flossing just this one time?) Daniel Goldstein makes tools that help us imagine ourselves over time, so that we make smart choices for Future Us.
1310.author: Daniel Goldstein
1310.keywords: TED, talks, behavioral economics, business, culture, decision-making, economics, finance, self

1311.title: There are no scraps of men
1311.description: Alberto Cairo's clinics in Afghanistan used to close down during active fighting. Now, they stay open. In this powerful talk, Cairo tells the moving story of why -- and how he found humanity and dignity in the midst of war.
1311.author: Alberto Cairo
1311.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, disability, global issues, poverty, prosthetics, storytelling, war, work

1312.title: How healthy living nearly killed me
1312.description: For a full year, A.J. Jacobs followed every piece of health advice he could -- from applying sunscreen by the shot glass to wearing a bicycle helmet while shopping. Onstage at TEDMED, he shares the surprising things he learned.
1312.author: A.J. Jacobs
1312.keywords: TED, talks, culture, entertainment, health, humor, self, comedy

1314.title: The global power shift
1314.description: Paddy Ashdown believes we are living in a moment in history where power is changing in ways it never has before. In a spellbinding talk he outlines the three major global shifts that he sees coming.
1314.author: Paddy Ashdown
1314.keywords: TED, talks, Europe, Foreign Policy, TEDx, global issues, politics, world cultures

1318.title: Be suspicious of simple stories
1318.description: Like all of us, economist Tyler Cowen loves a good story. But in this intriguing talk, he asks us to step away from thinking of our lives -- and our messy, complicated irrational world -- in terms of a simple narrative.
1318.author: Tyler Cowen
1318.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, business, culture, economics, storytelling

1320.title: Award-winning teenage science in action
1320.description: In 2011 three young women swept the top prizes of the first Google Science Fair. Lauren Hodge, Shree Bose and Naomi Shah describe their extraordinary projects -- and their route to a passion for science.
1320.author: Lauren Hodge, Shree Bose + Naomi Shah
1320.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, cancer, medicine, pollution, science, youth, chemistry, health, food, code

1321.title: In defense of dialogue
1321.description: In politics, it seems counterintuitive to engage in dialogue with violent groups, with radicals and terrorists, and with the states that support them. But Jonas Gahr Støre, the foreign minister of Norway, makes a compelling case for open discussion, even when our values diverge.
1321.author: Jonas Gahr Støre

1323.title: "Women of Hope"
1323.description: Inspired by Aung San Suu Kyi's call to action, "If you're feeling helpless, help someone," Morley composed this song. She sings it at TEDxWomen in her gorgeous, warm voice.
1323.author: Morley
1323.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, activism, music, poetry, women, live music, performance

1324.title: Thorium, an alternative nuclear fuel
1324.description: Kirk Sorensen shows us the liquid fuel thorium reactor -- a way to produce energy that is safer, cleaner and more efficient than current nuclear power.
1324.author: Kirk Sorensen
1324.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, alternative energy, nuclear energy, technology

1325.title: The debut of the British Paraorchestra
1325.description: There are millions of prodigiously gifted musicians of disability around the world, and Charles Hazlewood is determined to give them a platform. Watch the debut performance of the British Paraorchestra.
1325.author: Charles Hazlewood + British Paraorchestra
1325.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, disability, entertainment, global issues, live music

1326.title: Meet the Water Canary
1326.description: After a crisis, how can we tell if water is safe to drink? Current tests are slow and complex, and the delay can be deadly, as in the cholera outbreak after Haiti's earthquake in 2010. TED Fellow Sonaar Luthra previews his design for a simple tool that quickly tests water for safety -- the Water Canary.
1326.author: Sonaar Luthra
1326.keywords: TED, talks, TED Fellows, design, technology, water, global development

1327.title: Atheism 2.0
1327.description: What aspects of religion should atheists (respectfully) adopt? Alain de Botton suggests a "religion for atheists" -- call it Atheism 2.0 -- that incorporates religious forms and traditions to satisfy our human need for connection, ritual and transcendence.
1327.author: Alain de Botton
1327.keywords: TED, talks, atheism, culture, philosophy, religion

1329.title: Why SOPA is a bad idea
1329.description: What does a bill like PIPA/SOPA mean to our shareable world? At the TED offices, Clay Shirky delivers a proper manifesto -- a call to defend our freedom to create, discuss, link and share, rather than passively consume.
1329.author: Clay Shirky
1329.keywords: TED, talks, business, creativity, media, politics, technology

1330.title: How to make choosing easier
1330.description: We all want customized experiences and products -- but when faced with 700 options, consumers freeze up. With fascinating new research, Sheena Iyengar demonstrates how businesses (and others) can improve the experience of choosing.
1330.author: Sheena Iyengar
1330.keywords: TED, talks, business, choice, culture, decision-making, marketing

1331.title: The beautiful math behind the world's ugliest music
1331.description: Scott Rickard set out to engineer the ugliest possible piece of music, devoid of repetition, using a mathematical concept known as the Costas Array. In this surprisingly entertaining talk, he shares the math behind musical beauty ... and its opposite.
1331.author: Scott Rickard
1331.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, entertainment, math, music, science, science and art, algorithm, composing, collaboration

1332.title: Plant fuels that could power a jet
1332.description: Algae plus salt water equals ... fuel? At TEDxNASA@SiliconValley, Bilal Bomani reveals a self-sustaining ecosystem that produces biofuels -- without wasting arable land or fresh water.
1332.author: Bilal Bomani
1332.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, science, sustainability, technology, green, engineering, alternative energy, energy, biotech, environment, innovation, future, climate change, oceans, ecology, nature, solar energy, plants, synthetic biology, natural resources

1334.title: Is there a real you?
1334.description: What makes you, you? Is it how you think of yourself, how others think of you, or something else entirely? Philosopher Julian Baggini draws from philosophy and neuroscience to give a surprising answer.
1334.author: Julian Baggini
1334.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, neuroscience, philosophy, self, TEDYouth, personality

1335.title: A primer on 3D printing
1335.description: 2012 may be the year of 3D printing, when this three-decade-old technology finally becomes accessible and even commonplace. Lisa Harouni gives a useful introduction to this fascinating way of making things -- including intricate objects once impossible to create.
1335.author: Lisa Harouni
1335.keywords: TED, talks, business, design, technology, 3D printing, manufacturing

1336.title: Extreme swimming with the world's most dangerous jellyfish
1336.description: In the 1970s, Diana Nyad set long-distance swim records that are still unbroken. Thirty years later, at 60, she attempted her longest swim yet, from Cuba to Florida. In this funny, powerful talk at TEDMED, she talks about how to prepare mentally to achieve an extreme dream, and asks: What will YOU do with your wild, precious life?
1336.author: Diana Nyad
1336.keywords: TED, talks, culture, extreme sports, fear, sports, success

1337.title: Doctors make mistakes. Can we talk about that?
1337.description: Every doctor makes mistakes. But, says physician Brian Goldman, medicine's culture of denial (and shame) keeps doctors from ever talking about those mistakes, or using them to learn and improve. Telling stories from his own long practice, he calls on doctors to start talking about being wrong.
1337.author: Brian Goldman
1337.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, communication, culture, medicine, public health

1339.title: Women entrepreneurs, example not exception
1339.description: Women aren't micro--so why do they only get micro-loans? Reporter Gayle Tzemach Lemmon argues that women running all types of firms-- from home businesses to major factories-- are the overlooked key to economic development.
1339.author: Gayle Tzemach Lemmon
1339.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, entrepreneur, global issues, poverty, women, women in business

1341.title: What happens inside those massive warehouses?
1341.description: We make millions of online purchases daily, but who (or what) actually puts our items into packages? In this talk, Mick Mountz weaves a fascinating, surprisingly robot-filled tale of what happens inside a warehouse.
1341.author: Mick Mountz
1341.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, business, consumerism, robots, shopping, technology

1343.title: Treating cancer with electric fields
1343.description: Surgery, chemotherapy and radiation are the best-known methods for treating cancer. At TEDMED, Bill Doyle presents a new approach, called Tumor Treating Fields, which uses electric fields to interrupt cancer cell division. Still in its infancy -- and approved for only certain types of cancer -- the treatment comes with one big benefit: quality of life.
1343.author: Bill Doyle
1343.keywords: TED, talks, cancer, medical research, technology

1346.title: Back to the future (of 1994)
1346.description: From deep in the TED archive, Danny Hillis outlines an intriguing theory of how and why technological change seems to be accelerating, by linking it to the very evolution of life itself.  The presentation techniques he uses may look dated, but the ideas are as relevant as ever.
1346.author: Danny Hillis
1346.keywords: TED, talks, future, science, technology, math, history, life, human origins, genetics, molecular biology, evolution, computers, innovation, DNA, programming, engineering

1347.title: The secret structure of great talks
1347.description: From the "I have a dream" speech to Steve Jobs' iPhone launch, many great talks have a common structure that helps their message resonate with listeners. In this talk, presentation expert Nancy Duarte shares practical lessons on how to make a powerful call-to-action.
1347.author: Nancy Duarte
1347.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, communication, presentation, storytelling

1349.title: How your brain tells you where you are
1349.description: How do you remember where you parked your car? How do you know if you're moving in the right direction? Neuroscientist Neil Burgess studies the neural mechanisms that map the space around us, and how they link to memory and imagination.
1349.author: Neil Burgess
1349.keywords: TED, talks, brain, cognitive science, exploration, neuroscience, science, physiology, biology, algorithm, biotech

1351.title: Globalizing the local, localizing the global
1351.description: Sheikha Al Mayassa, a patron of artists, storytellers and filmmakers in Qatar, talks about how art and culture create a country's identity -- and allow every country to share its unique identity with the wider world. As she says: "We don't want to be all the same, but we do want to understand each other."
1351.author: Sheikha Al Mayassa
1351.keywords: TED, talks, Islam, Middle East, art, cities, culture, film

1353.title: Impossible photography
1353.description: Erik Johansson creates realistic photos of impossible scenes -- capturing ideas, not moments. In this witty how-to, the Photoshop wizard describes the principles he uses to make these fantastical scenarios come to life, while keeping them visually plausible.
1353.author: Erik Johansson
1353.keywords: TED, talks, creativity, culture, photography, technology

1354.title: Deaf in the military
1354.description: Keith Nolan always wanted to join the United States military. The challenge: he is Deaf, which is an automatic disqualification according to military rules. In this talk, he describes his fight to fight for his country. (In American Sign Language with real-time interpretation by Rita Alexander)
1354.author: Keith Nolan
1354.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, disability, global issues, military

1356.title: The toxic baby
1356.description: Filmmaker Penelope Jagessar Chaffer was curious about the chemicals she was exposed to while pregnant: Could they affect her unborn child? So she asked scientist Tyrone Hayes to brief her on one he studied closely: atrazine, a herbicide used on corn. (Hayes, an expert on amphibians, is a critic of atrazine, which displays a disturbing effect on frog development.) Onstage together at TEDWomen, Hayes and Chaffer tell their story.
1356.author: Tyrone Hayes + Penelope Jagessar Chaffer
1356.keywords: TED, talks, animals, biology, children, film, plastic, science, sex, pregnancy, public health, science and art, pollution, cancer, chemistry, environment, health, ecology, activism, agriculture, sustainability

1361.title: How mobile phones power disaster relief
1361.description: The disastrous earthquake in Haiti taught humanitarian groups an unexpected lesson: the power of mobile devices to coordinate, inform and guide relief efforts. At TEDxRC2, Paul Conneally shows extraordinary examples of social media and other technologies becoming central to humanitarian aid.
1361.author: Paul Conneally
1361.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, disaster relief, global issues, natural disaster, social media, technology

1363.title: Look up for a change
1363.description: How often do you see the true beauty of the night sky? TED Fellow Lucianne Walkowicz shows how light pollution is ruining the extraordinary -- and often ignored -- experience of seeing directly into space.
1363.author: Lucianne Walkowicz
1363.keywords: TED, talks, TED Fellows, TEDx, environment, global issues, science, space, NASA, pollution, Planets, activism, technology, universe

1364.title: 2600 years of history in one object
1364.description: A clay cylinder covered in Akkadian cuneiform script, damaged and broken, the Cyrus Cylinder is a powerful symbol of religious tolerance and multi-culturalism. In this enthralling talk Neil MacGregor, Director of the British Museum, traces 2600 years of Middle Eastern history through this single object.
1364.author: Neil MacGregor
1364.keywords: TED, talks, culture, global issues, history, world cultures, archaeology

1365.title: Comedy is translation
1365.description: Every act of communication is, in some way, an act of translation. Writer Chris Bliss talks about the way that great comedy can translate deep truths for a mass audience.
1365.author: Chris Bliss
1365.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, communication, entertainment, humor, language, literature, comedy

1366.title: Using tech to enable dreaming
1366.description: Has our technology -- our cell phones and iPods and cameras -- stopped us from dreaming? Young artist Shilo Shiv Suleman says no, as she demos "Khoya," her new storybook for iPad, which floats us through a magical world in 7 minutes of pure creativity.
1366.author: Shilo Shiv Suleman
1366.keywords: TED, talks, art, creativity, Best of the Web

1367.title: Saving for tomorrow, tomorrow
1367.description: It's easy to imagine saving money next week, but how about right now? Generally, we want to spend it. Economist Shlomo Benartzi says this is one of the biggest obstacles to saving enough for retirement, and asks: How do we turn this behavioral challenge into a behavioral solution?
1367.author: Shlomo Benartzi
1367.keywords: TED, talks, behavioral economics, economics, money, psychology

1369.title: The sibling bond
1369.description: Were you the favorite child, the wild child or the middle child? Jeffrey Kluger explores the profound life-long bond between brothers and sisters, and the influence of birth order, favoritism and sibling rivalry.
1369.author: Jeffrey Kluger
1369.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, life, psychology, science, compassion, happiness, humanity, family, anthropology, sociology, brain

1370.title: All your devices can be hacked
1370.description: Could someone hack your pacemaker? Avi Rubin shows how hackers are compromising cars, smartphones and medical devices, and warns us about the dangers of an increasingly hack-able world.
1370.author: Avi Rubin
1370.keywords: TED, talks, Internet, TEDx, computers, hack, security, technology, encryption

1371.title: Why videos go viral
1371.description: Kevin Allocca is YouTube's Head of Culture & Trends, and he has deep thoughts about silly web video. In this talk from TEDYouth, he shares the 4 reasons a video goes viral.
1371.author: Kevin Allocca
1371.keywords: TED, talks, TEDYouth, entertainment, online video, social media

1372.title: A census of the ocean
1372.description: Oceanographer Paul Snelgrove shares the results of a ten-year project with one goal: to take a census of all the life in the oceans. He shares amazing photos of some of the surprising finds of the Census of Marine Life.
1372.author: Paul Snelgrove
1372.keywords: TED, talks, biology, collaboration, fish, oceans, photography, marine biology, global commons

1373.title: The ocean's shifting baseline
1373.description: The ocean has degraded within our lifetimes, as shown in the decreasing average size of fish. And yet, as Daniel Pauly shows us onstage at Mission Blue, each time the baseline drops, we call it the new "normal." At what point do we stop readjusting downward?
1373.author: Daniel Pauly
1373.keywords: TED, talks, data, oceans, science, mission blue, fish, climate change, environment, ecology, animals, biodiversity, pollution, conservation, future, prediction, population, marine biology

1374.title: The Earth is full
1374.description: Have we used up all our resources? Have we filled up all the livable space on Earth? Paul Gilding suggests we have, and the possibility of devastating consequences, in a talk that's equal parts terrifying and, oddly, hopeful.
1374.author: Paul Gilding
1374.keywords: TED, talks, cities, science, sustainability, technology, climate change, environment, alternative energy, activism, agriculture, economics, solar energy, energy, future, green, natural resources

1375.title: Abundance is our future
1375.description: Onstage at TED2012, Peter Diamandis makes a case for optimism -- that we'll invent, innovate and create ways to solve the challenges that loom over us. "I’m not saying we don’t have our set of problems; we surely do. But ultimately, we knock them down.”
1375.author: Peter Diamandis
1375.keywords: TED, talks, cities, invention, sustainability, technology

1378.title: We need to talk about an injustice
1378.description: In an engaging and personal talk -- with cameo appearances from his grandmother and Rosa Parks -- human rights lawyer Bryan Stevenson shares some hard truths about America's justice system, starting with a massive imbalance along racial lines: a third of the country's black male population has been incarcerated at some point in their lives. These issues, which are wrapped up in America's unexamined history, are rarely talked about with this level of candor, insight and persuasiveness.
1378.author: Bryan Stevenson
1378.keywords: TED, talks, crime, culture, global issues, inequality, law, race, criminal justice, justice system

1379.title: The clues to a great story
1379.description: Filmmaker Andrew Stanton ("Toy Story," "WALL-E") shares what he knows about storytelling -- starting at the end and working back to the beginning. Contains graphic language ... (Note: this talk is not available for download.)
1379.author: Andrew Stanton
1379.keywords: TED, talks, entertainment, film, storytelling, animation, art

1380.title: Why I must speak out about climate change
1380.description: Top climate scientist James Hansen tells the story of his involvement in the science of and debate over global climate change. In doing so he outlines the overwhelming evidence that change is happening and why that makes him deeply worried about the future.
1380.author: James Hansen
1380.keywords: TED, talks, big problems, climate change, environment, global issues, science

1381.title: Coding a better government
1381.description: Can government be run like the Internet, permissionless and open? Coder and activist Jennifer Pahlka believes it can -- and that apps, built quickly and cheaply, are a powerful new way to connect citizens to their governments -- and their neighbors.
1381.author: Jennifer Pahlka
1381.keywords: TED, talks, activism, cities, government, technology

1383.title: Design to challenge reality
1383.description: Kelli Anderson shatters our expectations about reality by injecting humor and surprise into everyday objects. She shares her disruptive and clever designs.
1383.author: Kelli Anderson
1383.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, art, design, materials

1385.title: The cockroach beatbox
1385.description: By dissecting a cockroach ... yes, live on stage ... TED Fellow and neuroscientist Greg Gage shows how brains receive and deliver electric impulses -- and how legs can respond. This talk comes from the TED-Ed project.
1385.author: Greg Gage
1385.keywords: TED, talks, TED Fellows, TED-Ed, brain, life, neuroscience, science, technology, biology, physiology, insects, nature, sound, humor

1389.title: Religion, evolution, and the ecstasy of self-transcendence
1389.description: Psychologist Jonathan Haidt asks a simple, but difficult question: why do we search for self-transcendence? Why do we attempt to lose ourselves? In a tour through the science of evolution by group selection, he proposes a provocative answer.
1389.author: Jonathan Haidt
1389.keywords: TED, talks, culture, evolution, religion, evolutionary psychology

1390.title: The $8 billion iPod
1390.description: Comic author Rob Reid unveils Copyright Math (TM), a remarkable new field of study based on actual numbers from entertainment industry lawyers and lobbyists.
1390.author: Rob Reid
1390.keywords: TED, talks, business, entertainment, humor, music, comedy

1392.title: Beautiful artificial limbs
1392.description: Prosthetics can't replicate the look and feel of lost limbs but they can carry a lot of personality. Designer Scott Summit shows 3D-printed, individually designed prosthetic legs that are unabashedly artificial and completely personal -- from macho to fabulous.
1392.author: Scott Summit
1392.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, beauty, design, industrial design, prosthetics

1394.title: Let's transform energy -- with natural gas
1394.description: The US consumes 25% of the world's oil -- but as energy tycoon T. Boone Pickens points out onstage, the country has no energy policy to prepare for the inevitable. Is alternative energy our bridge to an oil-free future? After losing $150 million investing in wind energy, Pickens suggests it isn't, not yet. What might get us there? Natural gas. After the talk, watch for a lively Q&A with TED Curator Chris Anderson.
1394.author: T. Boone Pickens
1394.keywords: TED, talks, alternative energy, culture, economics, energy, technology

1396.title: The single biggest health threat women face
1396.description: Surprising, but true: More women now die of heart disease than men, yet cardiovascular research has long focused on men. Pioneering doctor C. Noel Bairey Merz shares what we know and don't know about women's heart health -- including the remarkably different symptoms women present during a heart attack (and why they're often missed).
1396.author: Noel Bairey Merz
1396.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, health, heart health, medical research, medicine, science, women, public health, politics, activism, physiology, medical imaging, illness, health care, biology, disease

1397.title: Yup, I built a nuclear fusion reactor
1397.description: Taylor Wilson believes nuclear fusion is a solution to our future energy needs, and that kids can change the world. And he knows something about both of those: When he was 14, he built a working fusion reactor in his parents' garage. Now 17, he takes the TED stage at short notice to tell (the short version of) his story.
1397.author: Taylor Wilson
1397.keywords: TED, talks, energy, science, technology, youth, nuclear energy, physics, alternative energy, invention, innovation, chemistry, future

1398.title: Everyday moments, caught in time
1398.description: Combining dry wit with artistic depth, Billy Collins shares a project in which several of his poems were turned into delightful animated films in a collaboration with Sundance Channel. Five of them are included in this wonderfully entertaining and moving talk -- and don't miss the hilarious final poem!
1398.author: Billy Collins
1398.keywords: TED, talks, culture, entertainment, humor, poetry

1399.title: Let's talk about dying
1399.description: We can't control if we'll die, but we can "occupy death," in the words of Peter Saul, an emergency doctor. He asks us to think about the end of our lives -- and to question the modern model of slow, intubated death in hospital. Two big questions can help you start this tough conversation.
1399.author: Peter Saul
1399.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, death, global issues, health, health care

1400.title: Make data more human
1400.description: Jer Thorp creates beautiful data visualizations to put abstract data into a human context. At TEDxVancouver, he shares his moving projects, from graphing an entire year's news cycle, to mapping the way people share articles across the internet.
1400.author: Jer Thorp
1400.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, data, design, media, news

1401.title: The missing link to renewable energy
1401.description: What's the key to using alternative energy, like solar and wind? Storage -- so we can have power on tap even when the sun's not out and the wind's not blowing. In this accessible, inspiring talk, Donald Sadoway takes to the blackboard to show us the future of large-scale batteries that store renewable energy. As he says: "We need to think about the problem differently. We need to think big. We need to think cheap."
1401.author: Donald Sadoway
1401.keywords: TED, talks, alternative energy, energy, invention, technology, electricity

1402.title: From mach-20 glider to hummingbird drone
1402.description: "What would you attempt to do if you knew you could not fail?" asks Regina Dugan, then director of DARPA, the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency. In this breathtaking talk she describes some of the extraordinary projects -- a robotic hummingbird, a prosthetic arm controlled by thought, and, well, the internet -- that her agency has created by not worrying that they might fail. (Followed by a Q&A with TED's Chris Anderson)
1402.author: Regina Dugan
1402.keywords: TED, talks, drones, flight, innovation, military, science, technology, physics, biomimicry, invention, design, robots, nanoscale, biology, weather, materials, birds, prosthetics, Vaccines, neuroscience, health, Internet, community, engineering, nature, children, product design, rocket science

1403.title: Unlock the intelligence, passion, greatness of girls
1403.description: Nobel Peace Prize winner Leymah Gbowee has two powerful stories to tell -- of her own life's transformation, and of the untapped potential of girls around the world. Can we transform the world by unlocking the greatness of girls?
1403.author: Leymah Gbowee
1403.keywords: TED, talks, global issues, peace, social change, women

1404.title: Building blocks that blink, beep and teach
1404.description: Imagine a set of electronics as easy to play with as Legos. TED Fellow Ayah Bdeir introduces littleBits, a set of simple, interchangeable blocks that make programming as simple and important a part of creativity as snapping blocks together.
1404.author: Ayah Bdeir
1404.keywords: TED, talks, TED Fellows, creativity, education, technology, toy, code

1405.title: A magical tale (with augmented reality)
1405.description: Marco Tempest spins a beautiful story of what magic is, how it entertains us and how it highlights our humanity -- all while working extraordinary illusions with his hands and an augmented reality machine.
1405.author: Marco Tempest
1405.keywords: TED, talks, art, design, entertainment, illusion, magic, technology

1406.title: Inventing is the easy part. Marketing takes work
1406.description: Solar-powered LED lightbulbs could transform the lives of rural Haitians, but as Daniel Schnitzer found, they don't simply sell themselves. At TEDxPittsburgh, he shows how smart health and energy products for the developing world are useless unless the market works too.
1406.author: Daniel Schnitzer
1406.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, alternative energy, global issues, green, poverty, technology

1407.title: I am a pirate
1407.description: The Pirate Party fights for transparency, anonymity and sensible copyright laws. At TEDxOslo, Rick Falkvinge explains how he became the leader of Europe's tech-driven political party, which so far has won 17 seats across national parliaments in Europe.
1407.author: Rick Falkvinge
1407.keywords: TED, talks, Internet, TEDx, global issues, politics, technology

1409.title: Connected, but alone?
1409.description: As we expect more from technology, do we expect less from each other? Sherry Turkle studies how our devices and online personas are redefining human connection and communication -- and asks us to think deeply about the new kinds of connection we want to have.
1409.author: Sherry Turkle
1409.keywords: TED, talks, AI, communication, community, culture, sociology, technology

1410.title: Designing books is no laughing matter. OK, it is.
1410.description: Chip Kidd doesn't judge books by their cover, he creates covers that embody the book -- and he does it with a wicked sense of humor. In this deeply felt (and deeply hilarious) talk, he shares the art and the philosophy behind his cover designs. (This talk is from The Design Studio session at TED2012, guest-curated by Chee Pearlman and David Rockwell.)
1410.author: Chip Kidd
1410.keywords: TED, talks, creativity, design, humor, literature

1411.title: On the virtual dissection table
1411.description: Onstage at TED2012, Jack Choi demonstrates a powerful tool for training medical students: a stretcher-sized multi-touch screen of the human body that lets you explore, dissect and understand the body's parts and systems.
1411.author: Jack Choi
1411.keywords: TED, talks, health care, interface design, medical research, technology

1412.title: The other inconvenient truth
1412.description: A skyrocketing demand for food means that agriculture has become the largest driver of climate change, biodiversity loss and environmental destruction. Jonathan Foley shows why we desperately need to begin "terraculture" -- farming for the whole planet.
1412.author: Jonathan Foley
1412.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, agriculture, environment, global issues, global commons

1413.title: How can technology transform the human body?
1413.description: TED Fellow Lucy McRae is a body architect -- she imagines ways to merge biology and technology in our own bodies. In this visually stunning talk, she shows her work, from clothes that recreate the body's insides for a music video with pop-star Robyn, to a pill that, when swallowed, lets you sweat perfume.
1413.author: Lucy McRae
1413.keywords: TED, talks, TED Fellows, architecture, design, smell, technology, human body

1415.title: "Put the financial aid in the bag"
1415.description: At TEDYouth 2011, performance artist Carvens Lissaint shows how to use language, metaphor and imagery to express a powerful idea -- as in this spoken-word performance, a stirring plea to make college education more accessible.
1415.author: Carvens Lissaint
1415.keywords: TED, talks, TED-Ed, culture, entertainment, language, poetry, youth, TEDYouth

1416.title: Half a million secrets
1416.description: "Secrets can take many forms -- they can be shocking, or silly, or soulful." Frank Warren, the founder of PostSecret.com, shares some of the half-million secrets that strangers have mailed him on postcards.
1416.author: Frank Warren
1416.keywords: TED, talks, creativity, design, memory, storytelling, community

1418.title: Let's put birth control back on the agenda
1418.description: Contraception. The topic has become controversial in recent years. But should it be? Melinda Gates believes that many of the world's social change issues depend on ensuring that women are able to control their rate of having kids. In this significant talk at TEDxChange, she makes the case for the world to re-examine an issue she intends to lend her voice to for the next decade.
1418.author: Melinda Gates
1418.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, culture, global issues, health care, population, sex

1420.title: Building US-China relations ... by banjo
1420.description: Abigail Washburn wanted to be a lawyer improving US-China relations -- until she picked up a banjo. The TED Fellow tells a moving story of the connections she's formed touring across the US and China while playing that banjo and singing in Chinese.
1420.author: Abigail Washburn
1420.keywords: TED, talks, Asia, TED Fellows, china, culture, entertainment, music, world cultures, live music

1421.title: How do we heal medicine?
1421.description: Our medical systems are broken. Doctors are capable of extraordinary (and expensive) treatments, but they are losing their core focus: actually treating people. Doctor and writer Atul Gawande suggests we take a step back and look at new ways to do medicine -- with fewer cowboys and more pit crews.
1421.author: Atul Gawande
1421.keywords: TED, talks, health care, heart health, medicine

1422.title: How I beat a patent troll
1422.description: Drew Curtis, the founder of fark.com, tells the story of how he fought a lawsuit from a company that had a patent, "...for the creation and distribution of news releases via email." Along the way he shares some nutty statistics about the growing legal problem of frivolous patents.
1422.author: Drew Curtis

1423.title: The stories behind the bloodlines
1423.description: Taryn Simon captures the essence of vast, generation-spanning stories by photographing the descendants of people at the center of the narrative. In this riveting talk she shows a stream of these stories from all over the world, investigating the nature of genealogy and the way our lives are shaped by the interplay of many different forces.
1423.author: Taryn Simon
1423.keywords: TED, talks, art, culture, global issues, photography

1425.title: Tracking ancient diseases using ... plaque
1425.description: Imagine what we could learn about diseases by studying the history of human disease, from ancient hominids to the present. But how? TED Fellow Christina Warinner is an achaeological geneticist, and she's found a spectacular new tool -- the microbial DNA in fossilized dental plaque.
1425.author: Christina Warinner
1425.keywords: TED, talks, TED Fellows, ancient world, bacteria, evolution, medicine, paleontology, science, biology, anthropology, disease, food, genetics, history, health, innovation

1426.title: Is our universe the only universe?
1426.description: Is there more than one universe? In this visually rich, action-packed talk, Brian Greene shows how the unanswered questions of physics (starting with a big one: What caused the Big Bang?) have led to the theory that our own universe is just one of many in the "multiverse."
1426.author: Brian Greene
1426.keywords: TED, talks, String theory, cosmos, physics, science, time, universe, Planets, space, astronomy, exploration, math, dark matter, big bang

1429.title: The 4 commandments of cities
1429.description: Eduardo Paes is the mayor of Rio de Janeiro, a sprawling, complicated, beautiful city of 6.5 million. He shares four big ideas about leading Rio -- and all cities -- into the future, including bold (and do-able) infrastructure upgrades and how to make a city "smarter."
1429.author: Eduardo Paes
1429.keywords: TED, talks, Brazil, TED Prize, cities, technology, urban planning, infrastructure, South America

1430.title: Texting that saves lives
1430.description: When Nancy Lublin started texting teenagers to help with her social advocacy organization, what she found was shocking -- they started texting back about their own problems, from bullying to depression to abuse. So she's setting up a text-only crisis line, and the results might be even more important than she expected.
1430.author: Nancy Lublin
1430.keywords: TED, talks, activism, bullying, culture, global issues, health, youth

1431.title: How to use a paper towel
1431.description: You use paper towels to dry your hands every day, but chances are, you're doing it wrong. In this enlightening and funny short talk, Joe Smith reveals the trick to perfect paper towel technique.
1431.author: Joe Smith
1431.keywords: TED, talks, TEDx, entertainment, green, hack, humor, materials, simplicity

1434.title: A 40-year plan for energy
1434.description: In this intimate talk filmed at TED's offices, energy innovator Amory Lovins shows how to get the US off oil and coal by 2050, $5 trillion cheaper, with no Act of Congress, led by business for profit. The key is integrating all four energy-using sectors—and four kinds of innovation.
1434.author: Amory Lovins
